OVERVIEW: The Tranquillity series consists of very deep, somewhat poorly drained, saline-sodic soils on low-lying alluvial fans and flood plains.  It formed in alluvium derived dominantly from igneous and sedimentary rock.  Slope ranges from 0 to 1 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is about 8 inches, the mean annual air temperature is 62 to 64 degrees F, and the frost-free period is 245 to 255 days.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic, thermic Sodic Haploxererts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Tranquillity clay, saline-sodic, wet - on a nearly level slope of less than 1 percent in a cultivated fallow field at 172 feet elevation. (Colors are for air dry soil unless otherwise stated).  When described April 22, 1986, the soil was dry from 0 to 6 inches and moist below.)
Ap1--0 to 6 inches; grayish brown (2.5Y 5/2) clay; dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) moist; strong coarse subangular blocky structure, extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; common very fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; violently effervescent, carbonates disseminated, calcium carbonate equivalent is 3 percent; electrical conductivity is 2.6 decisiemens per meter; sodium adsorption ratio is 14; cation exchange capacity is 34.2 centimoles per kilogram; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); abrupt smooth boundary.  (2 to 6 inches thick).
Ap2--6 to 16 inches; grayish brown (2.5Y 5/2) clay; dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure, very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; violently effervescent, carbonates disseminated and segregated as few fine irregularly shaped concentrations, calcium carbonate equivalent is 4 percent; common fine irregularly shaped gypsum crystals, gypsum content is less than 1 percent; electrical conductivity is 8.7 decisiemens per meter; sodium adsorption ratio is 24; cation exchange capacity is 35.3 centimoles per kilogram; moderately alkaline (pH 8.3); abrupt smooth boundary.  (8 to 12 inches thick).
Bknyss1--16 to 31 inches; grayish brown (2.5Y 5/2) clay; dark grayish brown (2.5Y 4/2) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure, very hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; common intersecting slickensides; strongly effervescent, carbonates disseminated and segregated as common fine filaments, calcium carbonate equivalent is 4 percent; common fine irregularly shaped gypsum crystals, gypsum content is 1 percent; electrical conductivity is 10.7 decisiemens per meter; sodium adsorption ratio is 28; cation exchange capacity is 36.6 centimoles per kilogram; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); abrupt smooth boundary.  (14 to 16 inches thick).
Bknyss2--31 to 48 inches; light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/4) clay; olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) moist; massive, hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine tubular pores; common intersecting slickensides; few fine prominent, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist, irregularly shaped masses of iron accumulation; accumulation of iron masses are recent redoximorphic features; strongly effervescent, carbonates disseminated and segregated as common fine filaments, calcium carbonate equivalent is 4 percent; common fine irregularly shaped gypsum crystals, gypsum content is 2 percent; electrical conductivity is 10.9 decisiemens per meter; sodium adsorption ratio is 29; cation exchange capacity is 35.3 centimoles per kilogram; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); abrupt smooth boundary.  (15 to 19 inches  thick).
Bkny--48 to 65 inches; light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/4) silty clay; olive brown (2.5Y 4/4) moist; massive, hard, firm, sticky and very plastic; few very fine tubular pores; strongly effervescent, carbonates disseminated and segregated as common fine filaments, calcium carbonate equivalent is 4 percent; common fine irregularly shaped gypsum crystals, gypsum content is 6 percent; electrical conductivity is 12.6 decisiemens per meter; sodium adsorption ratio is 33; cation exchange capacity is 33.3 centimoles per kilogram; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); abrupt smooth boundary.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Fresno County, California; approximately 3 miles south of the community of Mendota and 210 feet north of Adams Avenue; approximately 142 feet south and 1,500 feet west of the northeast corner of section 19, T. 14 S., R. 15 E. MDB&M; Latitude 36 degrees 42 minutes 17 seconds north and Longitude 120 degrees 22 minutes 17 seconds west; USGS Tranquillity topographic quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Unless irrigated, vertical cracks extend from the surface and range from 0.5 to 2 inches wide at a depth of 20 inches.  The cracks usually close from December thru April for 100 to 151 consecutive days.  Common intersecting slickensides occur in some horizon or horizons below a depth of 16 inches.  The mean annual soil temperature is 59 to 64 degrees F.  Organic matter content is 0.5 to 2 percent from 0 to 6 inches depth and less than 1 percent below a depth of 6 inches.  It has 1 to 5 percent calcium carbonate equivalent as carbonates disseminated or segregated.  Gypsum content is 0 to 10 percent.  Electrical conductivity is 1 to 16 decisiemens per meter.  Sodium adsorption ratio is 2 to 50.  It is typically saline-sodic in most of the profile.  Clay content is 40 to 60 percent.
The Ap horizon has dry color of 5Y 4/1, 5/1, 5/2; 2.5Y 5/2, 5/3, 5/4, 6/2, 6/3, or 6/4 and moist color of 5Y 4/1, 4/2, 4/3, 4/4; 2.5Y 4/2, 4/3 or 4/4.  Calcium carbonate equivalent is 1 to 5 percent.  Gypsum content is 0 to 3 percent.  Electrical conductivity is 1 to 15 decisiemens per meter.  Sodium adsorption ratio is 2 to 40.
The B horizon has dry color of 5Y 5/2, 6/1, 6/2;  2.5Y 5/2, 6/2 6/3, or 6/4 and moist color of 5Y 5/1; 2.5Y 4/2, 4/3, 4/4, 5/2 or 5/3.  In the lower part of the B horizon moist redoximorphic features are distinct or prominent and have color of 2.5Y 2/0, 2/1, 5/4; 2.5YR 4/4, 4/6; 7.5YR 4/2, or 4/4.  It is clay or silty clay.  Calcium carbonate equivalent is 1 to 5 percent.  Gypsum content is 0 to 10 percent.  Electrical conductivity is 1 to 16 decisiemens per meter.  Sodium adsorption ratio is 13 to 50.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no competing series.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Tranquillity soils are on low-lying alluvial fans and flood plains.  Slope ranges from 0 to 1 percent.  Elevation is 150 to 205 feet.  The soils formed in alluvium derived dominantly from igneous and sedimentary rock.  The climate is arid with hot dry summers and cool, somewhat moist winters.  Fog is common in the winter.  The mean annual precipitation is 7 to 8 inches.  Mean January temperature is about 44 degrees F; mean July temperature is about 81 degrees F; mean annual temperature ranges from 62 to 64 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 245 to 255 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Cerini (T), and Lillis (T) series.  Cerini soils are well drained and fine-loamy.  Lillis soils have electrical conductivity greater than 15 decisiemens per meter within 1 meter of the surface.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Somewhat poorly drained, runoff is low; very slow permeability.  An apparent water table is at a depth of 4 to 6 feet or greater.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for irrigated crops such as cotton, wheat and alfalfa.  They are also used for wildlife habitat and recreation on a wildlife management area.  Vegetation on wildlife management areas consists primarily of timothy, watergrass and saltbush (Atriplex spp.).

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Central San Joaquin Valley, California.  The series is moderately extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Fresno County, California, 1995.  Tranquillity soils are named after the Tranquillity USGS topographic quadrangle and the community of Tranquillity.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Previously mapped as Oxalis series in the Soil Survey of the Mendota Area, California, Series 1940, No. 18.
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:

ADDITIONAL DATA.content: ADDITIONAL DATA:  Characterization data sample numbers 86P3123-3127 for the typical pedon.  Other characterization data sample numbers are 88P1470-1477, and 85P5357-5362.
